senses.definition: ' pace yourself'  If you pace yourself, you do not work or run as fast as you possibly could, because you want to be able to keep doing it for a long time without getting tired.
example: We'll have to work at a faster pace. [j33] I can't keep up with the pace of city life
Take two paces to the left
I've paced out the room, and it's not big enough to fit the furniture in
My kids know so much about computers[j4]I can't keep pace with them. [j33] The union claimed that wage rises hadn't kept pace with inflation
I paced up and down in the corridor while I waited to hear if the operation had succeeded
I paced myself to finish the marathon in five hours

definition: A pacifist is someone who believes that it is wrong to use violence or fight wars to resolve conflicts
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun pacifism'

definition: If you pacify someone, you make them less angry.
example: Martin was furious, but I managed to pacify him by promising it would be his turn next

senses.definition: ' pains'  If you take pains to do something, you make a considerable effort over it.  You try very hard to do it well.
example: Carla suffered a lot of pain from her sprained ankle. [j33] I felt a sudden pain in my chest
Neelam's bad behaviour caused her mother a lot of pain
' a pain in the neck'  In informal language, if you say someone is a pain in the neck, you mean that they are very irritating and annoying
Everyone went to great pains to make the office party a success. [j33] Sanjay was at pains to explain why I hadn't gained promotion
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective painful' The bruise was very painful.  It was painful to leave my family behind.[j35]'adverb painfully'

senses.definition: a' The past is the time before now, and all the things that happened then.
example: Mother just can't forget the past. [j33] In the past, people used horses as a means of transport
' past continuous'  In English grammar, the past continuous is another expression for the imperfect tense

' simple past'  In English grammar, the simple past is the tense you use to say that something happened before now, without saying anything about when it happened in relation to other events.  'I went', 'she sang' and 'he worked' are examples of the simple past

The jury was persuaded by the prosecutor's forceful argument. [j33] Her distress persuaded me that she was genuinely sorry
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun persuasion' She resisted all my attempts at persuasion.[j35]'adjective persuasive' He made me a very persuasive offer.

definition: If someone is pert, they are very pleased with themselves and are a bit rude or cheeky
In formal language, if you say that something is  pertinent, you mean that it is relevant.  It has to do with the matter being discussed.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun pertinence'
example: I don't think your question is pertinent[j4]we're talking about salaries, not holi-[fj days. [j33] Kimberley's just made a very pertinent point

definition: If something perturbs you, it worries or disturbs you.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun perturbance' She showed not the slightest perturbance at the news.
example: I was perturbed that he seemed so unhappy. [j33] The increase in violent crime is most perturbing. [j33] He refused to let the initially poor results perturb him

definition: If someone is perverse, they are deliberately awkward.

senses.definition: ' If you pervert something, you change it for the worse, or interfere with it so as to alter the final outcome.
example: You encourage immoral behaviour
If you lie under oath, you can be charged with perverting the course of justice
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective perverted' I don't know how anyone can enjoy such perverted activities.[j35] 'noun perversion'

senses.definition: ' If you pet an animal or a child, you stroke it or pat it lightly to show your affection for it.

definition: If you describe a woman or girl as petite, you mean that she is small and delicate.

definition: Pewter is a metal which is a dull silvery colour

definition: A phantom is a ghost.

definition: A pharmacist is someone who is qualified to prepare and dispense medicines for sick people.

example: If you need a cold remedy, consult your pharmacist

definition: If you have a phobia about something, you have an irrational fear of it.

senses.definition: ' pick up'   (a) If you pick something up, you lift or raise it, usually with your hands.  The opposite of this is put down.
example: Please don't pick the flowers in the Botanical Gardens. [j33] I got a seasonal job picking grapes

Sam's very aggressive[j4]he's always picking a fight with someone
' A pick is a garden tool which you use to break up hard soil or rock.  It consists of a curved metal bar with sharp ends which is attached at its centre to a wooden handle
Is Rajiv sick?  He only picked at his lunch
Why are you always picking on me?  The others are just as bad

I picked up the book and looked at the title. [j33] Please pick your clothes up off the floor. [j33] The crane picked up the statue and carried it over the fence. '   (b) '[cf2] If you pick something up, you buy or acquire it without making a particular effort. [cf2]Could you pick up a loaf at the shops? [j33] She's picked up some interesting objects on her travels. [j33] I picked up a nasty bug last week. [j33] I picked up a bit of Spanish from my cousin. '   (c) '[cf2] If you pick someone up, you call for them, usually in a car, and then you go somewhere together.  [cf2]I'll pick you up at 7.30 and we should be there by 8. '   (d) '[cf2] If you pick someone up, you meet them and become sexually or romantically involved with them straight away. [cf2]Carlos picked up a new girl at the pub last Friday. 8 ' take your pick'  '[cf2] If you can take your pick of several things, you are able to choose whichever you want. '   (c) '[cf2] If you pick someone up, you call for them, usually in a car, and then you go somewhere together.  [cf2]I'll pick you up at 7.30 and we should be there by 8. '   (d) '[cf2] If you pick someone up, you meet them and become sexually or romantically involved with them straight away. ' pipe down'  In informal language, if you tell someone to pipe down, you want them to stop making so much noise

note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb pipe' He piped the water from the dam up to the house.

senses.definition: ' A pirate is a sailor who attacks other ships at sea and steals their cargo
example: This happened often in the past, and still goes on in and near the China Sea
' If someone pirates something that someone else has invented, designed or composed, they steal that person's ideas and use them without paying a royalty
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun piracy (piracies)'

definition: A pistol is a small gun

definition: A piston is a part of an engine consisting of a short cylinder that moves up and down or backwards and forwards inside another cylinder

senses.definition: ' the pits'  In informal language, if you say that something is the pits, you mean that it is very bad and unpleasant.

[cf2]Pit your wits against your friends in our popular weekly quizes. [j33] He pitted his wits against his rival in a bid to win promotion
The food in the canteen here is the pits. [j33] Having to stay in on a day like this is the pits

definition: A pitfall involved in doing something is a possible negative consequence or unforeseen danger if you aren't very careful.
example: The plan seems good, but what are the pitfalls? [j33] One of the pitfalls of training is the temptation to overdo it

definition: Pith is a fibrous substance that is found in plants, for example in citrus fruits, between the peel and the juicy flesh of the fruit
note: [j34] ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective pithy (pithier, pithiest)' Her comments are rather pithy[j4]she doesn't waste words.

senses.definition: ' If something is pitiful, it is completely inadequate.
example: Rosita lost all her family and possessions in the fire[j4]it's pitiful. [j33] The sick animal gave a pitiful whimper

definition: A pittance is a very small amount of money.

example: A plain carpet will tend to show up any marks and stains

It was plain that he wasn't interested. [j33] Have I made myself plain?  This is not to happen again. [j33] They're rewriting the leaflets in plain English instead of legal jargon
At school she was always rather plain and serious
There were several police in plain clothes among the crowd, hoping to catch the pickpockets in the act
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb plainly' I could see the outline very plainly.

senses.definition: ' If you plaster something somewhere, you apply a lot of it rather carelessly.
example: It is used to line the inside walls and the ceilings of houses and other buildings
' A plaster is a dressing that you put on a minor cut or burn. It has a small patch of gauze and adhesive strips so that you can stick it to your body and peel it off again
Don't plaster the icing over the cake[j4]try to spread it evenly. [j33] Her face was plastered with make-up. [j33] The walls were plastered with posters advertising the concert
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb plaster' The walls still need to be plastered and decorated.[j35]'noun plasterer' George is a good plasterer[j4]he always does a professional job.[j35]'adjective See plastered'.

senses.definition: ' have a lot on your plate'  In informal language, if you say you have a lot on your plate, you mean that you are very busy and you have a great deal to cope with.
example: She stacked the dirty plates in the dishwasher. [j33] I buttered the roll on my side plate. [j33] Plastic or paper plates are more practical for a picnic

I can't take on any more at the moment[j4]I've got enough on my plate as it is

example: The Atherton Tableland is a well-known plateau in the Great Dividing Range in northern Queensland

example: After the dessert they served a cheese platter

definition: If something is plausible, it seems likely to be true.  It is not difficult to believe.

senses.definition: ' A postscript is a short message which you write at the very end of a letter, after you've signed your name.  Usually it is something you forgot to write in the main letter or it's about something that happened after you wrote it.

note: ... THE ABBREVIATION for this is PS.   2' 'noun A postscript is an additional piece of information about something that happened later. There's an interesting postscript to the story[j4]Sofia did marry him in the end.

senses.definition: ' gone to pot'  In informal language, if you say someone or something has gone to pot, you mean that they've got into a very bad state.
example: Throw a few more carrots into the pot
Dave made a fresh pot of tea. [j33] ...a pot of jam. [j33] ...a paint pot
Carlos told me he smokes pot, but he's never used hard drugs

senses.definition: ' If you pounce on a mistake that someone has made, you immediately take notice of it, and maybe get other people to take notice of it too.
example: The lion pounced on the zebra. [j33] The cat sat watching the mouse, and suddenly pounced
The boss was waiting at the door to pounce on anyone arriving late. [j33] She pounced on me at the end of the meeting and asked me to be on the committee
Make sure that your spelling is perfect, so they can't pounce on that

senses.definition: ' If your heart pounds, it beats very fast and noisily.

' The pound is also a unit of weight used in Britain, the USA and some other English-speaking countries.  It is equi~ [chvalent to 454 grams

I parked on a clearway and by the time I got back my car had been towed to the pound
She pounded the table with her fist in anger. [j33] He pounded frantically at the locked door
She pounded up the stairs and yelled at the kids to be quiet. [j33] A police officer came pounding round the corner in pursuit
I was so nervous that my heart began to pound. [j33] He flung himself over the finish with heart pounding and lungs bursting

senses.definition: ' pour in'  If things such as letters or messages pour in, a lot of them arrive at the same time from many different places.
example: I poured the syrup all over the pudding. [j33] The milk was sour, so I poured it down the drain. [j33] Can I pour you another glass of wine? [j33] The molten metal is poured into the moulds
It was pouring with rain, so we decided to stay at home. [j33] At first it was only a light drizzle, but soon it began to pour. [j33] Outside the rain was pouring down, but we were snug
The audience poured out of the hall at the end of the concert
AAA Investments have poured more than $100 000 into the motor repair business
When he died, letters of sympathy poured in to his family from all over the world

senses.definition: ' In mathematics, a power of a number is that number multiplied by itself a certain number of times.
senses.rest: ' '  A p@wEr p@i:nt i:s a:n @u:tlEt f@r[fj [cb8][mgdi:ct_p@wErp@i:nt,-4][mgdi:ct_p@wErp@i:nt,-1][@l0][cb0][qr

The USA is a world power. [j33] The regional managers are the real powers in the corporation
The train runs on steam power
I'll have to turn off the power to install the light fitting. [j33] We had a power cut last night
16 is the fourth power of 2

Her office was decorated with 19th- century prints
' in print'  If a book is in print, it is still being sold by the publisher and you can buy or order it from a bookshop
' out of print'  If a book is out of print, it is no longer being sold by the publisher and you cannot get it from a bookshop that sells only new books

rainproof and '[cf2]stainproof, which are not formal. [cf2]Bars on doors and windows made the house proof against robbery

definition: If you prop something somewhere, you put it in a position where it is supported by something behind it.

definition: Propaganda is information that is given in order to make people hold a certain point of view.

definition: If a force propels something, it acts on it and causes it to move.

senses.definition: ' put up with'  If you put up with something, you tolerate it even though you don't like it.
example: Could you put the plates and glasses on the table? [j33] I put my hand on hers. [j33] We've put up new curtains in the lounge room. [j33]I only put my bag down for a moment and someone stole it

Steve has put a lot of time into this assignment. [j33] Her father agreed to put $10 000 into the business. [j33] You only get as much out of a relationship as you're prepared to put in. 3 ' '[cf2]verb If you put something that you say or write in a particular way, that is how you express it. [cf2]Let's put it this way: I won't be upset if she decides to leave. [j33] You need to put your main point more forcefully

I'll put your proposal to the boss, but I don't think she'll go along with it. [j33] I put it to you that your statement is a complete fabrication. 5 ' put away'  '[cf2] If you put something away, you place it where it is usually stored.  [cf2]Put your toys away now, please. [j33] I emptied the dishwasher and put away the dishes
I hate it when Dad puts me down in front of my friends. '   (b) '[cf2] When a vet puts down an animal, they kill it humanely.  [cf2]Unfortunately we had to have our old dog put down last week

I meant to go and visit her, but somehow I kept putting it off. [j33] We decided to put off our expedition in view of the rain. '   (b) '[cf2] If something puts you off, it discourages you or makes you less keen about doing something. [cf2]Don't let her manner put you off[j4]she's very nice really. [j33] I wanted to learn Japanese, but I got put off when I found out how hard it was. [j33] The dirt in the kitchen really put me off
He took off his shorts and put on a pair of trousers
I've been putting up with a toothache rather than go to the dentist

senses.definition: ' puzzle over'  If you puzzle over something, you spend a lot of time trying to understand it or work it out.
example: It's a puzzle how the vase got broken while we were all out. [j33] Mathematics has always been a hopeless puzzle to me
I bought a book of puzzles for the journey. [j33] The point of this puzzle is to separate the two metal rings. [j33] ...a crossword puzzle. [j33] ...a jigsaw puzzle
Mary puzzles me with her mood changes. [j33] What puzzles me is where he got the money from
I'm still puzzling over her sudden disappearance. [j33] Poor Jenny sat upstairs puzzling over her homework
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective puzzled' She looked at me with a puzzled expression.[j35]'adjective puzzling' Scientists are investigating this puzzling phenomenon.
